statement:
Let $(C,\Delta,\varepsilon)$ and $(D,\Delta',\varepsilon')$ be
coalgebras. Recall, that if $D_0\subseteq D$ is a subcoalgebra, then
$(D_0,\Delta'_{| D_0},\varepsilon'_{| D_0})$ is a coalgebra. On the
other hand, if $I\subseteq C$ is a coideal, then there is a canonical
coalgebra structure on $C/I$ (please, see for more details).

**Theorem.** If $f:C\to D$ is a coalgebra homomorphism, then
$\mathrm{ker}(f)$ is a coideal, $\mathrm{im}(f)$ is a subcoalgebra and a
mapping $f':C/\mathrm{ker}(f)\to\mathrm{im}(f)$ defined by
$f'\big( c+\mathrm{ker}(f)\big) =f(c)$ is a well defined coalgebra
isomorphism.
